properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Potential snow for the BC South Coast Thursday night to Friday morning With the shift into cooler weather, snow is looking likely over the BC South Coast this week. While there may be a few light flurries mixed with rain tonight, the first real opportunity for widespread low elevation snow is shaping up to be Thursday night. A low tracking south along the BC coast will spread moisture across the BC South Coast beginning Thursday evening. With temperatures hovering near the freezing mark, a mix of rain or snow is forecast across the region. As is frequently the case, snowfall amounts will vary across the region with elevation and proximity to the ocean. The latest computer guidance suggests that the Fraser Valley, Howe Sound, and higher elevations of Metro Vancouver and Vancouver Island have the potential for snowfall accumulations to exceed 5 cm Thursday night through Friday morning. The snow is expected to change to rain near mid-day Friday. More snow is possible this weekend as a series of weather systems embedded in a cool northwest flow from the Gulf of Alaska moves ashore. Early next week, very cold arctic air from the BC Interior will arrive on the South Coast. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-09T17:35:24-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-09T01:36:24-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1629742582.2020

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A major low pressure system will affect the province of Quebec on Saturday and Sunday. Precipitation will begin Saturday as rain over Southern Quebec and is expected to change over to freezing rain Saturday evening. The amount of freezing precipitation could be significant and make surfaces like roads, streets and sidewalks slippery and hazardous. Strong gusts of 60-70 km/h are also expected on Sunday, and may possibly impact icy structures such as tree limbs and power lines. There remains some uncertainty regarding the track of this system, which may affect total rainfall and freezing precipitation amounts. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-09T19:42:42-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant winter storm expected Saturday. A low pressure system will impact southern Ontario this weekend. Rain, freezing rain, and snow are all possible with this system. Significant rainfall amounts are expected for areas north of Lake Erie and Lake Ontario. Freezing rain is expected to affect most areas from east of Lake Huron to eastern Ontario. Significant ice accretion or build up is possible. Snow will affect areas east of Georgian Bay with significant snowfall amounts. Travel is expected to be impacted. There is still uncertainty as to which areas will be the most impacted with this system. The Ontario Storm Prediction Centre will be closely monitoring the situation. Warnings may be issued as the event draws nearer. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-09T18:50:42-00:00

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Maximum gusts: Southwesterly between 100 and 130 km/h. Locations: southern half of the Burin Peninsula, most of the Avalon Peninsula. Time span: until mid morning. Remarks: After the southwesterlies diminish this morning, winds will shift to northwesterly. Over the northern Avalon Peninsula winds will likely gust near 90 km/h this afternoon. Additionally, large waves and pounding surf are expected in Placentia and St. Mary's Bays early this morning. Water levels may be higher than normal during that time giving the potential for minor coastal flooding, especially near high tide. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. High winds may cause downed trees or toss loose objects. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-01-09T16:59:36-00:00

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. A trough of low pressure tracking eastward across the prairies has spread snow across southern Manitoba. The highest snowfall amounts are expected along and north of the Trans Canada highway and generally south of an east-to-west line through Gimli. Snowfall totals in the area are expected to be in the 10 to 15 cm range. Snow will taper off over western areas overnight and eastern areas Thursday morning. In addition to the snow, strong southeasterly winds gusting to 60 km/h will create reduced visibilities in blowing snow. Winds will diminish overnight. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.

properties.Summary:
Description: Snow and blowing snow expected today. Additional snowfall: near 5 cm, except up to 10 cm along parts of the northeast. Maximum wind gusts: generally northwesterly near 80 km/h. Locations: Port aux Basques to Gros Morne, Central and Northeastern Newfoundland. Time span: until late this afternoon. Remarks: Snow at times heavy will combine with strong winds to reduce visibility in blowing snow today. Conditions will gradually improve late today as winds and snow diminish. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Total snowfall: 40 to 60 cm with higher amounts likely over the Cape Breton Highlands. Location: Inverness, and Victoria Counties. Time span: tonight into Thursday morning. Remarks: Moderate to heavy snow will continue tonight before slowly tapering off through the day on Thursday. However isolated snow squalls are possible tonight and Thursday as colder air moves into the region. Total amounts could exceed 60 cm in areas of heaviest snow. In addition, strong northerly winds will continue to produce reduced visibility in blowing snow through tonight and Thursday morning. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-09T19:46:24-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-09T03:47:24-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3652221181.2020
Area: Inverness County - south of Mabou, Inverness County - Mabou and north, Victoria County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. Extreme cold wind chill values near -50 will affect regions north and west of Great Slave Lake tonight and into Thursday morning. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-09T20:23:51-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-09T04:24:51-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2489794940.2020
Area: Yellowknife Region, North Slave Region including Wekweeti - Whati - Behchoko, Lutsel K'e Region
properties.Author: Environment Canada
